sensors and can automatically detect and apprehend intruders. Upon sustaining
heavy damage, this piece of light weaponry will self-destruct soon after.

This behemoth was made by skydwellers to safeguard their treasure, but when the
magical contract detailing its task expires, it can turn against its creators.
Scholars say that the technological know-how needed to design golems isn't
native to Zegagrande, but rather was imported from another skydom long ago.

The winged beast takes great pride in its talons. Once one is able
to see through its arrogance, there is little else to fear from it.

These dragons have existed since antiquity and speak a unique tongue that
seemingly carries magical properties. Dragons mainly kill to eat but will defend
their territory fiercely against intruders. Run-ins with these grand creatures
are rare, for they dwell far from people and enjoy a life attuned to nature.

Legends tell of a firewyrm living in the burning belly of a volcano, nested atop
a fortress of gold, excavated by lava. Many have confronted the beast, whether for
fame, honor, or riches, but received only ashes and death in return. One breath from
this dragon invites a barrage of destruction from the skies to the depths of the abyss.

On a peak so high it nearly scrapes heaven's floor, the icewyrm roosts in a cave
of eternal ice. Only the best warriors who laugh at death venture here. Most now
persist as ice statues, their names long forgotten in the warm world below. Such
is the tale of mortal hubris—tiny people needling behemoths of frost.

Hoary-bearded veterans tell tales of the earthwyrm, of friends who set out to slay
it but never returned. They say that with just a roar, the beast sends islands
tumbling through the skies like windswept leaves. Bands of war-hardened brothers
and sisters, once fearsome to behold, lay trampled beneath its hulking claws.

When the clouds glow like gems in the sky, it's a sign the windwyrm is near. Its
existence is largely unknown, for the proud dragon only appears before the
worthy. But when a warrior of true caliber gazes up at iridescent skies, a gale
will pick up, the trees will bow, and the Storm Lord will descend from on high.

A flash of lightning descends a clear blue sky. A peal of thunder churns the
atmosphere, blasting tremors through the earth. The world is bathed in a silver
glow, and feather-like light particles hover in the air. Down comes the
whitewyrm to ask a single question: "Mortal. Dost thou wish for the end?"

Those who gaze into the murky abyss will hear a voice: "Thou who desirest
darkness, darkness also desireth thee." Instantly the sun shall be blotted out,
plunging the skies into pitch, and the blackwyrm will manifest. Night will
persist until a hero cleaves the dragon to let light spill forth once more.

Part of the Aviaeth mechanized arsenal, Tayu'itar are heavily armored assault
vehicles that travel on multiple legs. Each is equipped with an extensive armory
capable of battering an enemy battalion into dust.

A mysterious being in the shape of a familiar swordsman. A remnant of an 
immense, destructive power, it seems to straddle the boundary between
existence and nothingness. Its dark, shifting eyes gaze unflinchingly into the void.

Though massive, this desert serpent hides by tunneling deep beneath the sand,
where it can sense even the footfalls of a mouse scurrying across its territory.
A cobra on the hunt will surface suddenly and spit nerve poison into the face of
its prey, which the reptile produces in specialized internal organs.

This sturdy little dummy has been training great warriors since ages immemorial,
a wooden testament that every hero starts from zero. No one quite knows the
origin of the name, but here in Zegagrande, it's been affectionately dubbed Sir
Barrold.

These shadowy figures are spawned by Angra Mainyu, most often in swarms. 
No one knows what they are—only what they aren't. Humanoid in shape, the 
shades are not alive, nor do they possess any consciousness. They will assault 
any living thing in their vicinity, much like an automated weapon.

This colossal dragon acts as guardian to  and Lyria. Though
bound from snout to tail, it possesses the might to devastate all that
stands in the Grandcypher's path.

No one knows what the primal beast of dread truly looks like, for it is said to
shift into forms skydwellers find grotesque and terrifying. Vulkan Bolla absorbs
the fear of every person it meets, and this macabre energy transforms the land
around it into a burning hellscape.

This ominous mass is like a mirage of Vulkan Bolla—large, menacing, and
shimmering with heat. However, its only drive is to commit wanton acts of
destruction. Because this facsimile possesses no sense of self-preservation, its
attacks are even more reckless and ruthless than those of Vulkan Bolla itself.

The primal beast of vitality generally resembles a centaur of monumental size,
with wraiths of green smoke whirling pell-mell beneath layers of armor. However,
when in mortal danger, Furycane will shed its armor and manifest in its true
form.

Though this ominous mass resembles Furycane, its true identity remains a
mystery. It possesses no consciousness and bears more resemblance to a natural
disaster than a living creature, discharging destructive gales on a whim. It
wields a blade of black wind capable of parting even Furycane's tempests.

The primal beast of sequestration manipulates blizzards to rob its targets of
mobility. Based on how a battle develops, the wolf-like giant switches between
two forms. Speed Managarmr is light and charges down foes with a pair of spired
horns; power Managarmr is heavily armored and rolls over enemies like a tank.

Though this ominous mass possesses all of Managarmr's physical features, it
lacks a mind and soul. Because it does not fear pain, the facsimile can unleash
ruinous, self-destructive attacks, making it a more terrible foe than even
Managarmr itself.

The primal beast of fortification is so colossal that a city was built on top of
it. It's so heavy that, by simply striding across the land, it can flatten whole
civilizations. It also has numerous weapons built into its terrible frame,
including high-output energy cannons and multi-launch homing missile systems.

The primal beast of gates can open interdimensional portals—a dangerous power to
be sure. Thus the Astrals didn't endow the primal with a will of its own, using
it mainly as a mode of transport. In time, fueling the creature became
untenable. It was scrapped, only to be brought back by Lilith many years later.

After absorbing the power of multiple primal beasts, Angra Mainyu regained its
original, consummate form. It commands an inordinate amount of energy—enough
to open a gate to the Astral Realm—but should it ever exercise this ability,
the fallout would efface the skies.

After the Astral Lilith fused with Angra Mainyu, what she gained in power,
she lost in reason. A creature of pure ego and impulse, the Lilith amalgam
demands worship and seeks the eradication of all who resist its will.

This dragon—clad in royalty's hue—is destruction incarnate and doppelganger to
one half the god of all creation. Sensing a buildup of Astral power, Bahamut
Versa traveled from another dimension to the Sky Realm, where Lilith sealed it
inside Id to be unleashed again when the occasion suited her.

These curious extensions of Angra Mainyu are akin to immune cells the host sends
out of its body to dispatch invaders. They are capable of opening and traveling
through small interdimensional portals.

These large extensions of Angra Mainyu are akin to a defense mechanism for
obstructing invaders. Watchers generally occupy an alternate dimension,
projecting only a translucent image of themselves onto this plane; to remove
them, the invader must seek them out in the root dimension.

Everyone could use a little dragon pal like Vyrn.
's lucky to have such a good friend.

This little red dragon has been by 's
side since  was a wee babe. They
grew up together on the island of Zinkenstill.
Nothing gets on his nerves more than being called 
cute, a pet, or—worst of all—a lizard. He has been
known to boast of being a dragon who's as mighty
as he is cool.

A young girl with the power to control primal
beasts. When she shared her life force with
, their fates became inextricably linked.

Lyria's mysterious ability to bring primal beasts
under her control caught the attention of the
Erste Empire. The imperials locked her away for
further research and assigned her a guard,
Katalina, to make sure she couldn't escape.
Thankfully for Lyria, Katalina sympathized with
the girl and freed her from captivity. Together
they fled from the empire, eventually running into
 on Zinkenstill.  stood up
to Lyria's imperial pursuers and was killed for
the act of bravery. Filled with guilt and remorse,
Lyria was compelled to save the courageous
bystander's life by sharing her own. Ever since
that day, her fate has been intertwined with that
of 's.

While attempting to pacify the primal beast of
Tempeal, Lyria is kidnapped without warning by the
Church of Avia.

The Lyria that stood before 's crew 
on Mt. Neigelith was unlike the Lyria they had
always known. Why was she obeying Id's every
command when he was clearly the enemy? The
crew tried desperately to reach her, but it was no
use—the girl's eyes remained vacant.

Thanks to the crew's tireless efforts, Lyria has
been safely rescued from Avia. In fact, her life
link with  is stronger than ever.

A merchant who runs the Knickknack Shack. She
provides supplies, headhunting services, and jobs
for skyfarers across the Sky Realm.

Also known as Siero of the Knickknack Shack, this
diminutive punster provides goods, materials, and
personnel to skyfaring crews, and she also tracks
and handles job requests. Like most Harvins, her
youthful appearance belies an untold wealth of
wisdom and experience, which she's more than
willing to share—to the right patron.

A vicar employed at Folca's church. He moonlights
as the local handyman, earning him the nickname
'Mr. Fix It.'

Rolan is a vicar for Folca's church who also
moonlights as a handyman of sorts. The townsfolk
fully trust his compassionate nature, coming to
him with personal problems, broken furniture, and
other odd jobs. A skilled swordsman in his own
right, he's sometimes dispatched to exterminate
monsters. Yet for how much the townsfolk treat him
like a longtime neighbor, they don't know much
about his life before Folca.

In truth, Rolan is an Astral who possesses
unfathomable magic power. Over time, the people of
Folca—and skydwellers in general—have become like
family to him. And now that Lilith intends to hurt
his loved ones, he'll stake everything to stop
her.

Rolan dove into the dimension sealing Bahamut
Versa, saving Id and  in the nick of
time. Unfortunately, he was trapped in the process.

Thanks to the efforts of Id and , 
Rolan was able to return safely from the 
dimensional rift. Setting foot on home soil in 
Folca, he expresses his deepest thanks to 
 and company. He will return 
to his work as Mr. Fix It and will continue to 
watch over the people of Zegagrande.

The mysterious overseer of Mellose Monastery. Some
accuse her of being colder than Mt. Neigelith
itself.

Historiath heads Mellose Monastery, a holy place
situated in the mountains of Leautagne Island.
Adhering to the island's long-held traditions and
precepts, she oversees worship of the sacred Mt.
Neigelith and the primeval god it enshrines. She
comes to the crew's aid when Rolan, her old
friend, reveals Avia's brazen actions.

An information broker who operates from
Seedhollow.

Zathba runs the Family Zathba, an informant
network in the metropolis of Seedhollow. His
commodities are tips, rumors, and other intel
found throughout the Zegagrande Skydom, and his
clientele run the gamut from small-time
organizations to royalty. In recent years, he's
taken to investigating the Church of Avia.
Although gruff and hard to approach, he bears a 
sense of honor and social obligation that none can
deny. He's known Rolan for quite some time.
People who turn a blind eye
